questions.text: The World Health Organization (WHO) has defined blindness as a condition where the level of visual acuity is below
questions.explanation:
WHO Classification of Visual Impairment
  • The World Health Organization (WHO) defines blindness as "visual acuity of less than 3/60 (Snellen) or its equivalent".
  • The International Classification of Disease 11 (2018) classifies vision impairment into distance and near-presenting vision impairment

Classification

Visual Acuity

Mild Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/12

Moderate Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/18 (Option D ruled out)

Severe Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/60 (Option A ruled out)

Blindness

Presenting visual acuity worse than 3/60 (Option B)

Near Vision Impairment

Presenting near vision acuity worse than N6 or M0.8 at 40 cm with existing correction (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Which vaccine is linked to the risk of intussusception when administered?
Which of the following diseases is not included in the RBSK screening?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Congenital glaucoma

Aspect

Details

Program

Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)

Launched

2013 under the National Health Mission

Objective

Improve child health through early identification, screening, and management of health conditions among children aged 0 to 18 years

Target Conditions (4Ds)

Defects at Birth: Examples include cleft lip/palate, Down syndrome

Diseases: Examples include rheumatic heart disease

Deficiencies: Examples include anemia, Vitamin A deficiency

Developmental Delays including Disabilities

Screening Teams

Mobile health teams comprising a medical officer, staff nurse, and pharmacist

Screening Locations

Schools, Anganwadi centers, and homes

Referral System

District Early Intervention Centers (DEICs) for further management

Significance

Improves early detection and management of child health issues, reducing morbidity and enhancing quality of life

questions.text: Which of the following populations is not included in the HIV sentinel surveillance?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - STD clinic attendees.

Category

Details

Objective

Monitor trends in HIV prevalence, guide public health interventions, and identify high-risk populations.

Sentinel Sites

Specific locations for surveillance, including antenatal clinics, STD clinics, and high-risk community settings.

Populations Included

Antenatal Women: To estimate HIV prevalence in the general population.

High-Risk Groups: Female sex workers (FSWs), men who have sex with men (MSM), injecting drug users (IDUs).

Bridge Populations: Truck drivers, single male migrants.

Data Collected

HIV Prevalence: Percentage of individuals in the group who are HIV-positive.

Demographic Information: Age, gender, occupation, etc.

Risk Behavior: Sexual behavior, drug use, and other HIV transmission risk factors.

Key Features

Regular blood sample collection.

HIV testing conducted in sentinel sites.

Exclusions

STD clinic attendees may not be included as their data overlaps with other high-risk groups.

Importance

Tracks HIV trends over time.

Guides the allocation of resources.

Helps design targeted prevention programs for at-risk populations.

LOGO

DESCRIPTION

(A)

(C)

  • The Ministry of Food Processing Industries has created an online system for licensing and monitoring all activities related to the enforcement and administration of FPO.
  • Regulates the quality of tinned fruit juices and tinned fruit cans.

(D)

  • AGMARK is a certification mark indicating that agricultural produce meets a grade standard specified by DMI

Before travel

questions.text: What is the quickest method for laboratory diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis?
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic Modality

Description

Usage

Sputum Smear Microscopy (Option B ruled out)

Microscopic examination of sputum samples to detect acid-fast bacilli (AFB).

Used for initial screening and diagnosis, especially in resource-limited settings.

Chest X-ray

Imaging done to identify abnormalities suggestive of TB.

Used to support diagnosis when clinical suspicion is high; not definitive for TB diagnosis.

TruNAAT/CBNAAT (Option A)

Molecular tests that detect Mycobacterial DNA and rifampicin resistance.

Recommended for initial diagnosis due to high sensitivity and specificity; rapid results.

Line Probe Assay (LPA)

Molecular test to detect specific genetic mutations associated with drug resistance (e.g., rifampicin, isoniazid).

Used for detecting drug resistance in confirmed TB cases, not for initial diagnosis.

Tuberculin Skin Test (TST)

A skin test to measure immune response to injected tuberculin protein.

Primarily used for screening latent TB infection; not specific for active TB diagnosis.

Interferon-Gamma Release Assays (IGRAs)

Blood cytokine analysis test that measures immune response to TB antigens.

Used for detecting latent TB infection

Sputum Culture (Option C ruled out)

 

Growing Mycobacteria from sputum samples to confirm TB and test for drug susceptibility.

Gold standard for TB diagnosis; takes several weeks to obtain results.

Drug Susceptibility Testing (DST)

Testing TB bacteria from patient samples to determine resistance to TB drugs.

Used to guide treatment by identifying drug-resistant strains in confirmed TB cases.

questions.text: As a medical officer posted in rural service, you have been asked to supervise the various preventive measures being taken in your region against malaria. According to the program whose logo is shown below, you would be correct to advise all of the following except:

options.text: Indoor residual sprays are not suitable for vector control in rural areas.

questions.correct_answer: C. Indoor residual sprays are not suitable for vector control in rural areas.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases are included in the scheme, which has the logo as given below?
questions.explanation:
Component

Initiatives

New Initiatives under NPCDCS
  1. Intervention for prevention and control of Rheumatic Heart Disease under NPCDCS and Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK).
  2. Integration of AYUSH with NPCDCS.
  3. Integration of RNTCP with NPCDCS to articulate a national strategy for management of TB and diabetes comorbidities in India.

Cancer Component under NPCDCS

Cancer Services under NPCDCS:

  • Providing common diagnostic services, basic surgery, chemotherapy, and palliative care for cancer patients at 100 district hospitals.
  • Supporting each district with chemotherapy drugs for 100 patients, establishing day-care chemotherapy facilities, and providing facilities for laboratory investigations, including mammography.
  • Offering home-based palliative care for chronic and progressive cancer patients in 100 districts.
  • Designating State Cancer Institutes (SCIs) as apex institutions for comprehensive cancer diagnosis, treatment, and care.
  • Strengthening 45 centres as Tertiary Cancer Centres (TCCs) to deliver comprehensive cancer care services.

questions.text: A' Bacteriologically Confirmed Case' in TB is defined as:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B) Sputum positive

Category

Description

Criteria/Features

Presumptive TB Case

 

Used in place of TB suspect. Individuals showing symptoms suggestive of TB but not yet confirmed.

-Cough, Fever, Night sweats +- Weight loss > 2 weeks (Option D ruled out)

Clinically Diagnosed TB Case

 

Sputum negative but with high clinical suspicion of TB. Used in place of Sputum negative TB case.

-Persistent symptoms despite negative sputum smear

- High clinical suspicion based on symptoms, radiological and histological features (Option A ruled out)

Bacteriologically Confirmed TB Case (Option B)

 

Biological specimen is positive for sputum AFB and/or CBNAAT. Used in place of Sputum positive TB case.

- Positive sputum smear for AFB

- Positive CBNAAT test confirming the presence of TB bacteria

questions.text: What type of blindness does the individual have if their right eye has a visual acuity of 6/60 and their left eye has a visual acuity of 3/60?
As part of the Anemia Mukt Bharat program, pregnant women with mild to moderate anemia who are less than 34 weeks pregnant are managed with the following treatment approach:

options.label: A
options.text: 2 iron and folic acid (IFA) tablets OD

options.label: B
options.text: IV iron sucrose for noncompliance with oral tablets

options.label: C
options.text: 2 iron and folic acid tablets OD + IV iron sucrose

questions.correct_answer: A. 2 iron and folic acid (IFA) tablets OD
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Reference:
  • ↳ https://nhm.gov.in/index1.php?lang=1&level=3&sublinkid=1448&lid=797 https://pmposhan.education.gov.in/aboutus.html https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/maternal-health/guidelines/5x5_matrix_2502.pdf https://wcd.nic.in/kishori-shakti-yojana
  • ↳ https://nhm.gov.in/index1.php?lang=1&level=3&sublinkid=1448&lid=797
  • ↳ https://pmposhan.education.gov.in/aboutus.html
  • ↳ https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/maternal-health/guidelines/5x5_matrix_2502.pdf
  • ↳ https://wcd.nic.in/kishori-shakti-yojana

6 INTERVENTIONS

6 STRATEGIES
  • Prophylactic iron-folic acid supplementation.
  • Deworming.
  • Intensified year-round behaviour change communication campaign (solid body, smart mind), including ensured delayed cord clamping.
  • Testing of anaemia using digital methods and point-of-care treatment.
  • Mandatory provision of iron folic acid fortified foods in public health programmes.
  • Addressing non-nutritional causes of anaemia in endemic pockets with a special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies, and fluorosis.
  • National Anaemia Mukt Bharat Unit.
  • Intra-ministerial coordination.
  • Strengthening supply chain and logistics.
  • Convergence with other ministries.
  • National Centre of Excellence and Advanced Research on Anaemia Control.
  • Anaemia Mukt Bharat dashboard and digital portal- One-stop shop for anaemia.

6 BENEFICIARIES
  • Children, 6-59 months of age (Bi-weekly Administer 1 ml of Iron and Folic Acid syrup containing 20 mg elemental iron and 100 mcg folic acid per dose)
  • Children, 5-9 years of age- pink tablets (Weekly administer one sugar-coated pink tablet of Iron and Folic Acid containing 45 mg elemental iron and 400 mcg folic acid)
  • Adolescent girls & boys (10-19 years of age)- blue tablets (Weekly administer one sugar-coated blue tablet of Iron and Folic Acid containing 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid)
  • Women of reproductive age group (20-24 years of age).(Weekly, administer one sugar-coated red tablet of Iron and Folic Acid containing 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid)
  • Pregnant women- Red tablets (180 tablets)Daily, 1 Iron and Folic Acid tablet should be taken starting from the fourth month of pregnancy (second trimester) and continued throughout the pregnancy (for at least 180 days). Each tablet contains 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid, is sugar-coated, and red in color.
  • Lactating mothers (of 0-6 months child)- Red tablets .The tablet should also be continued for 180 days post-partum. Each tablet contains 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid, is sugar-coated, and red in color.

questions.text: How much mg of iron and mcg of folic acid should a pregnant woman be given?
questions.explanation:
Age Group

Iron Dose & Frequency

Folic Acid Dose & Frequency

Infants (6-59 months)

1 ml IFA syrup (20 mg elemental iron, 100 mcg folic acid) biweekly

Included in syrup (100 mcg) biweekly

Preschool Children (5-9 years)

45 mg elemental iron + 400 mcg folic acid weekly

Included in tablet (400 mcg) weekly

Adolescents (10-19 years)

60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid weekly

Included in tablet (500 mcg) weekly

Pregnant & Lactating Women

60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid daily

Included in tablet (500 mcg) daily

Women of Reproductive Age (15-49 years)

60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid weekly

Included in tablet (500 mcg) weekly

questions.text: The biological method for Mosquito Larva control is done by?
questions.explanation:
Environmental measures

Chemical control

Biological control

Yield permanent results and source reduction.

 

E.g.

 

  • Filling drains and ditches.
  • Levelling of ground.
  • Proper drainage of breeding areas.
  • Intermittent irrigation.
  • Changing water alkalinity.

Using larvicides

 

E.g.

 

1. Physical:

  • MLO (Mosquito larvicidal oil): 200L/hectare

2. Chemical:

  • Paris green
  • Temephos (Abate): 200L/hectare

3. IGR (insect growth regulators):

  • Inhibit chitin formation, moulding and adult maturation.
  • Pyriproxyfen and Diflubenzuron

Larvivorous Fishes:

 

1. Gambusia and Poecilia fish

2. Bacillus thuringiensis (used in polluted waters)

3. Toxorhynchites splendens

(predator mosquito for Aedes and Anopheles)

questions.text: Which of the following criteria would you utilize to evaluate the effectiveness of the malaria surveillance system implemented by the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B

Parameter

Definition

Purpose/Use

Annual Parasite Index (API)

Number of confirmed malaria cases per 1,000 population in a specific area within a year

Measures the incidence or burden of malaria in a population

Annual Blood Examination Rate (ABER)

Percentage of the population at risk of malaria who have undergone blood examination for malaria parasites

Assesses the coverage and efficiency of the surveillance system in terms of diagnostic testing for malaria

Slide Positivity Rate (SPR)

Percentage of blood slides examined that test positive for malaria parasites

Provides information about the proportion of individuals tested who have confirmed malaria infection

Slide Falciparum Rate (SFR)

Percentage of blood slides examined that test positive for Plasmodium falciparum

Focuses on the prevalence of P. falciparum infection among tested individuals
